column1: Temple Terrace is an incorporated city in northeastern Hillsborough County
column2: Florida
column3: United States
column4: adjacent to Tampa. As of the 2010 census
column5: the city had a population of 24
column6: 541. It is the third and smallest incorporated municipality in Hillsborough County. (Tampa and Plant City are the others.) Incorporated in 1925
column7: the community is known for its rolling landscape
column9: and majestic trees; it has the most grand sand live oak trees of any place in central Florida and is a Tree City USA. Temple Terrace was originally planned as a 1920s Mediterranean-Revival golf course community and is one of the first such communities in the United States (planned in 1920).

column1: Temple Terrace was named for the then-new hybrid
column2: the Temple orange
column3: also called the tangor. It is a cross between the mandarin orange — also called the tangerine — and the common sweet orange; it was named after Florida-born William Chase Temple
column4: one-time owner of the Pittsburgh Pirates
column6: and first president of the Florida Citrus Exchange. Temple Terrace was the first place in the United States where the new Temple orange was grown in large quantities. The "terrace" portion of the name refers to the terraced terrain of the area by the river where the city was founded. One of the original houses also had a terraced yard with a lawn sloping

column1: The original inhabitants of the Temple Terrace area were known as the Tocobaga
column2: a group of Native Americans living around Tampa Bay
column3: both in prehistoric and historic times
column4: until roughly 1760. Their numbers declined in the seventeenth century
column5: due at least in part to diseases brought to the New World by the Europeans
column6: to which they had little natural resistance. All of the Florida tribes were also severely affected by the raids of Creeks and Yamasee during the late stages of the seventeenth century. In any case
column7: the Tocobaga disappeared from history less than a hundred years later.

column1: Spanish exploration of the Temple Terrace area dates back to 1757 when explorer Don Francisco Maria Celi of the Spanish Royal Fleet made his way up the Hillsborough River (naming it "El Rio de San Julian y Arriaga") to what is now Riverhills Park in search of pine trees to use as masts for his ships. Here
column2: in the extensive longleaf pine forest
column3: he erected a cross in what he named "El Pinal de la Cruz de Santa Teresa" (the Pine Forest of the Cross of Saint Theresa). Confirmation of the fleet's travels is found in its map and log book. A historic marker and a replica of the cross erected to honor St. Theresa is found in Riverhills Park today. Up to 1913
column4: the longleaf pine
column6: and cypress trees made the area suitable for turpentine manufacturing and logging.

column1: The area now known as Temple Terrace was originally part of an exclusive 19
column2: 000-acre (77 km2) game preserve called "Riverhills" belonging to Chicago socialite Bertha Palmer
column3: wife of businessman Potter Palmer. She played an extensive role in making Sarasota the "City of the Arts" that it is today. She was one of the largest landholders
column4: ranchers
column6: and developers in Florida at the turn of the twentieth century. The Evening Independent newspaper in 1918 described the preserve as "a well stocked hunting preserve north of Tampa being one of the most attractive hunting grounds in the state." Property acquisition by the Palmers and the Honorés began in 1910; only one of the original buildings from the preserve
column7: now known as the Woodmont Clubhouse
column9: the grounds of the clubhouse harbor some of the largest specimens of live oak and longleaf pine in the city.

column1: === The Mediterranean Revival golf course community ===
Mrs. Potter-Palmer's vision for her property was that it be developed into a golf course community surrounded by extensive citrus groves
column2: but her death in 1918 prevented her from fully realizing that vision. At her death
column3: the trustee of her estate and brother
column4: Adrian Honoré
column5: sold her local land holdings to Burks Hamner
column10: who formed two development corporations: Temple Terrace Estates
column12: which developed the golf course and residential areas; and Temple Terraces
column15: 000 acres (20 km2) of orange groves that originally surrounded the city to the west and north
column16: the largest orange grove in the world in the 1920s. (Adrian Honoré retained a seat on the board.) D. Collins Gillett oversaw Temple Terraces
column17: Inc. and owned the first and largest citrus nursery in Florida
column18: Buckeye Nurseries of Tampa. His father
column21: was instrumental in popularizing the exotic hybrid Temple orange in the United States.

column1: The 1920 vision for the community was that wealthy retired Northerners would purchase one of the lots in Temple Terrace
column2: build a Mediterranean Revival villa on the lot and also purchase a parcel in the extensive adjoining citrus grove to either manage as a hobby or provide extra income. Temple Terrace was originally only occupied during "The Season" (which lasted roughly from December to the annual Washington Ball held at the clubhouse on February 22). The rest of the year the houses were cared for by caretakers until The Season came again and the homeowners returned.
part of the 5

column4: Inc. was developed into the present-day neighborhood of Temple Crest
column5: immediately adjacent to Temple Terrace and to its west
column6: hugging the Hillsborough River. The land occupied by nearby Busch Gardens was also part of Mrs. Palmer's original 19

column2: the Temple Terrace Golf and Country Club (which is still in existence) hosted the Florida Open (in 1925 billed as the "Greatest Field of Golfers ever to Play in Florida"). "Long" Jim Barnes was resident professional of the course at the time (James Kelly Thomson was the course's first pro)
column3: and every major golfer of the day competed in the event except for Bobby Jones. Leo Diegel won the tournament. Jim Barnes' friend Fred McLeod is also associated with the early days of the course. The golf-course architect was Tom Bendelow
column4: who also designed Medinah Country Club's Course #3 in Chicago
column7: 385 m) golf course which has hosted three U.S. Opens (1949
column10: 2006). The golf course of the Temple Terrace Golf and Country Club is virtually unchanged since its design by Bendelow and is eligible for the National Register of Historic Places. It measures 6

column1: Temple Terrace is one of the first planned golf-course communities in the United States (1920). The town plan was created by town planner and landscape architect George F. Young
column2: who also created the plan for nearby Davis Islands (Tampa) and McClelland Park (Sarasota)
column3: among others. The architecture was designed in the Mediterranean-Revival style by two different architects at two different time periods. The first phase was in 1921 by noted Tampa architect M. Leo Elliott (Centro Asturiano de Tampa and Old Tampa City Hall) who designed the initial houses and the public buildings. In 1926 renowned New York architect Dwight James Baum (architect of John Ringling's Cà d'Zan
column4: the Hotel El Verona in Sarasota
column5: and the West Side YMCA in New York City) also designed residences in Temple Terrace.

column1: There are fifteen houses and buildings designed by Elliott remaining in the city
column2: the largest collection of his work anywhere. In addition
column3: there are over 35 houses in the city designed by architect Dwight James Baum
column4: which is thought to be the largest collection of his work in the Southeast.

column1: Temple Terrace struggled through the 1930s like the rest of Florida. Building activity began to pick up again after World War II. There is now a fine collection of mid-century modern homes and buildings
column2: at least two of which were designed by well-known architect Frank Albert DePasquale.

column1: Florida Bible Institute bought the old Country Club Clubhouse in the late 1930s from the city for back taxes and remains a cherished part of Florida College. Florida College is now a private liberal arts college (founded in 1946) and occupies some of the community's oldest buildings
column2: including the Temple Terrace Country Club
column3: which is now Sutton Hall. Billy Graham attended Florida Bible Institute
column4: which owned the property now occupied by Florida College
column5: in the late 1930s. In his autobiography he writes that he received his calling "on the 18th green of the Temple Terrace Golf and Country Club". A Billy Graham Memorial Park is on the east side of the 18th green on the river.

column1: Temple Terrace rebirth took place in 1984–1987 with the appointment of Thomas C. Mortenson as the City's Building and Zoning Director and 1st Community Development Director [1].  Mortenson
column2: with the assistance of City Engineer Paul Tomasino
column3: and City Attorney Ted Taub
column4: were responsible for the annexation of Telecom Park and numerous areas adjacent to the city
column5: thereby tripling the tax base and doubling the size of the city.  Creating a favorable development environment and working with the Mayor and City Council
column6: the trio worked to attract new businesses
column8: as well as redevelopment of existing business areas and vastly expanded housing in the community.  Numerous new subdivisions were created during this period giving the city a firm tax base and identity that made Temple Terrace a desirable safe place for raising families
column9: conducting business and environmentally sound community [2].

column1: Temple Terrace is currently in the process of redeveloping 50 acres (200
column2: 000 m2) (the southeast quadrant) of its 1960s-era downtown. The goal of the city is to build a mixed-use
column3: medium-density
column4: pedestrian-oriented downtown.

column1: The city hired noted town planner Torti Gallas + Partners in 2004 to create a New Urbanist master plan and redevelopment code for the entire 225-acre (0.91 km2) downtown area (four quadrants of 56th Street and Busch Boulevard)
column2: all with citizen input. The city also initiated a form-based code for its downtown
column3: created a façade-improvement grant program
column4: implemented a multi-modal transportation model to encourage alternatives to the automobile
column5: and began revitalizing 56th Street with entry towers

column1: The site of the new downtown area is the site of the downtown area that was originally planned in the 1920s but never built because of the Great Depression. Many of the planning concepts and architecture of the redevelopment area are based on the original plan and Temple Terrace's unique 1920s historic Mediterranean Revival architecture.
Many of Temple Terrace's residents teach or work at the nearby University of South Florida
column2: and the close-knit community has strong ties to that institution. (The USF campus was also part of Mrs. Palmer's original 19
column3: 000-acre (77 km2) ranch.)

column2: located to the east of Temple Terrace
column3: is Hillsborough County's only botanical garden. The 31-acre (130
column4: 000 m2) park was started by Russian immigrant and amateur horticulturalist Albert Greenberg
column5: who donated his park to the county in 1967. Poet Robert Frost and other famous personalities made it a point to visit Greenberg in the years prior to World War II.
